name.label:
The success of the First Crusade meant that
the rulers of the newly established territories

The First Crusade anticipated a theocratic
state in Palestine[3]. 
The kingship of Jerusalem which the crusaders founded was elective

The kingdom of Jerusalem passed to Emperor Friedrich II after his marriage to the daughter of Jean de Brienne.  The titular right
to the kingdom passed to his grandson Konradin von Hohenstaufen

name.label: The name "Byzantium"

The emperor was
elected

Political power
in the empire shifted between dynasties

A complicated
hierarchy of titles developed in the empire

The present
document shows the descendants in the male line of all Roman and Byzantine
families which at some point in time provided an emperor or anti-emperor in the
east between 395 and 1057.  Later imperial families are treated in the separate
documents BYZANTIUM 1057-1204 and BYZANTIUM 1261-1453.  Byzantine nobles
families which never rose to imperial rank are set out in the documentBYZANTINE NOBILITY.

Byzantine
sources are numerous.  The focus has been on extracting information which
relates primarily to establishing the relationships in the Byzantine imperial
and noble families

The main primary
sources which have been consulted in detail in the preparation of the present
document are Iordanes

Reference has
also been made to the CD RomProsopography of the Byzantine Empire I

An earlier
version of this document was reviewed in detail by Morris Bierbrier
